I was wandering on Irving one day, craving boba, and had Wonderful Foods bookmarked on my Yelp account. I decided to give it a shot. 

The price was alright, but I definitely expected something straight out of the SGV from all the rave reviews. There was something definitely off about the tea, like it was oversteeped, and the boba wasn't a consistency that was appealing to me. I was pretty disappointed, and finished my drink as quickly as I could. My brother was also pretty unenthused about his drink. 

2 stars for their candy selection, clean bathrooms, & kind employees! Oh, and I believe they have durian smoothies, if you're into that.
author: Emily L.

description:
YUMMMYY

I've never actually stepped foot into the store so I can't write anything about lines yet or the experience, so this review is only for the drinks themselves (though I'm sure, I'll visit sooner or later since a certain mister really likes this place). But he'd go on a boba run and bring it back to Berkeley for me and dang it still tastes super delicious :) Though we've parked near it to go to TPumps before and I didn't see any crazy lines forming.

[Drinks] - def appreciate how nothing is crazy sweet nor artificial tasting.
Watermelon juice (real juice yayyyy!!!!) with boba - super refreshing and really hits the spot on a hot day. The boba is actually flavored, sweet, and its texture is pretty on point for excellent boba - soft and chewy.

Regular milk tea - yummm - really good especially with boba.

Avocado smoothie with boba - (real avocado - maybe a little too much) but it was still really good! So much potassium and fiber - it felt like a full meal going down. I still really enjoyed it being an avocado fiend and boba lover. 

This is Wonderful (:

Overall - 5 stars. Would recommend? YESSSSUMMMM :)))
author: Lynn L.

description:
As original as you can get...this is the place!

After a slew of new boba shops that has been opening up on Irving...competition has been tough but I think Wonderful has a good stance on all of it

Shop is not as fancy as some places but its simple and the menu is on the wall and hasnt really changed much over the years.

I always get their regular milk tea with boba and i have to say...its one of my go to places when im itching (always!) for milk tea....its has the nice combination of milk and tea with a bitterness that kind of reminds of me of coffee...without the coffee =P.

The boba is always al dente....as i read from someone's post....which is REALLY the best way of describing the boba.  The boba is also sweetened, but not fake super sweet sugar or whatever crap most places does it...it has a nice honey taste to it...which helps with the bitterness of the milk tea sometimes.
author: Laurie W.

description:
After having posted multiple tips, this place definitely deserves a review.

Quick line (if any), fast service, under $5, fresh ingredients, strong tea, and clean space.  I'm so sold.

Additionally, this place has candy, popcorn chicken, and tea eggs!  I'm not a big fan of candy in general, but they do have quite the variety lining the left and right walls.  

My go-to drinks:
1) Honey Green Tea, $3.50 (tapioca here is perfectly chewy but I prefer my tea without -- note, it's the same price with and without)
2) Plum Green Tea, $3.25
3) Banana Smoothie, $4.25
4) Blueberry Smoothie, $4.25
5) Lychee Milk Tea
6) Watermelon Juice
7) Thai Tea Tapioca

Just remember, it's cash only. 
(ATM for BofA is one block toward 19th)
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
Hands down one of the best boba places in SF and maybe the whole peninsula! They got some competition there on Irving with all the boba stores there (TPumps, Teaway, Quickly's, etc) but I'd come here no matter what! Loyal customer.

Small store. Has I think two small tables with four chairs total and lots of candy to your liking as you walk in. I'm not sure what the price is per pound of the candy but if you're craving candy and boba, two in one right here. And if you love tea eggs, it always smells like it in there (: Yum!

This place is cash only! But definitely bring some cash because you don't want to pass a place like this. I especially like their Almond and Lychee milk tea! Even the original is real good! 

Parking can be a pain depending on the time you come. Weekdays at noon are probably your best bet!
author: Joan T.

description:
How many sketchy "Best [insert food name here] in town" signs are actually accurate? This one might just be. Not to mention, the owners took a risk in self-proclaiming their shop as "wonderful"... I bet they're laughing because it turns out I actually can't say it's anything short of "spectacular."

The location and store itself looks pretty janky, with limited meter parking and an extremely Asian-looking store front. Plus, they also sell tons of candy in self-serve bins, which I found really strange. 

San Francisco's diverse culture shock aside, the drinks are BOMB. The Mango Tapioca is seriously one of the most memorable boba drinks I've ever had. I think I was expecting a standard milk tea, but instead received a naturally sweet, thick yet smooth, real mango flavored (not artificial) drink from heaven. You'll just have to try it for yourself! I tried my friends' drinks and they were made very well too, although I would ask for less sweet if you don't have as much of sweet tooth as me.

The boba, or tapioca, attains perfect chewiness with a subtle tinge of honey. I could probably eat a whole cup of those on their own. So yum.

Their snacks are like an elevated version of Quicklys'. I will never be able to eat the fries there again without comparing them to Wonderful's, because they were that good. Spicy fries. Get 'em. 

As if the boba and snacks weren't tempting enough, I had to close my eyes on the way out so I wouldn't end up succumbing to the likes of Panda Pocky and Peachie-O's lining the walls.
author: Yaoyao P.

description:
I'm a little torn by this place, I am not sure how I should feel because everyone says their boba is AMAZNG and I'm just like .... eh it was okay.

They do a traditional boba here, no fancy machines, no super crazy flavors, just solid boba flavors you'd normally find with good pearls. I guess the pearls are what they're known for? they just tasted chewy and good to me, no like OMG PEARLS WOW...

And the boba? It was actually a little too sweet for me despite asking for less sweet on the milk tea. I think maybe I just have this pre-conceived notion of what boba is supposed to taste like and what yummy boba is to me and this place didn't fit my taste buds that well.

With that said, everything was cheap so no complaints!
author: Lorrie M.

description: Cullen & I decided to try this place on a Tuesday night because we we're craving some boba. We walk in surprised that this place has so many reviews. Literally there's only one lady behind the counter whipping upher wonders. Two police officers were in front of us. They were kind of staring us down the way cops do. The lady gave the officer his drink and I couldn't help but ask the paranoid cop, "which drink did you get?" He told me it was avocado. Despite our differences, I decided that his choice of beverage was acceptable to my palate. The cops left in peace. Once the cops drove off and waved at us, I smiled and waved back. Then Cullen pulled out his pistol and I pulled out my hand gun. The Asian lady behind the counter started screaming. I told her to make me two advocado smoothies, and make it fast. I gotta say they were pretty good. Not too sweet.
author: Austin B.

description: While the food is good, the service needs a lot of work. Just because you have a good reputation, doesn't mean you can demean your customers.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
CASH ONLY!

the first boba place in town, and still the best! the menu is huge, so you really can't go wrong with anything you order. i think i've probably tried half the menu already! haha. they have some food items too! the salt/pepper chicken here is the best as well. ohhh... and the green onion pancake is a MUST when you have the munchies!
author: Ann T.

description:
To be honest, I was very very surprised that this place serves the "best boba in town". The name of the cafe is questionable, as is the ambiance. Walking in, there's a row of self-serve candy containers (??!) and the decor just looks cheap. 

Anyway, I ordered an unsweetened mango green tea... and got a mango SMOOTHIE. I asked the guy who made it what drink it was, and he INSISTED that it was a mango green tea. It was definitely a mango smoothie. I even watched him make it (though at the time I thought it was someone else's drink!!) I hate getting the wrong order, and I hate being lied to even more. 

Considering all the hype about this place, I'll have to try another drink before deciding yay/nay.. but as of now, the unfortunate order experience and price makes this place just *okay*.
author: Samantha C.

description: Awesome bubble tea - tapioca pearls were the perfect texture and I really enjoyed my milk tea! Ordered the salt and pepper chicken, which was delicious and a great deal at under $6. I also ordered the tempura, which I wasn't as big of a fan of. I was expecting vegetable tempura, but instead it came with deep fried baby octopuses and fish cakes. P.S. CASH ONLY!
author: Stacy K.

description:
Came yesterday and ordered a Wintermelon milk tea with boba...all I can say is yum, I think I've found a new favorite...for now. The concept of this drink is simple. Add wintermelon to black tea and blend, then add condensed milk or milk & sugar to sweeten. Most places end up making this tea far too sweet, but Wonderful did it right. 

Topped it off with their perfectly chewy and soft boba and the drink ended up being the perfect desert to top of the night.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
I used to love this place but my last few visits here were very disappointing. 

They used to produce milk teas with a good amount of tea, but those days are long gone. The last two times I came, I got some watered down version of a milk tea. Very disappointing when a cup is $3-$3.50 - not exactly chump change for flavored water. 

And so my search continues for a good milk tea establishment in the Bay Area! (Why is everything good in SoCal ??)
author: Mina K.

description:
This place is the default location for boba around my neighborhood. I still remember when Quickly first opened a block away, it was getting hyped up but their drinks still tasted super bland. This hole in the wall establishment makes some of the best tapioca drinks ever. I mean they don't let you customize the drinks like Teaway but they definitely get the flavors right.

I usually order the Taro Milk Tea whenever I drop by and it's awesome that they don't switch up the recipe at all. Last time I tried the same drink at Quickly, it turned out to be super watered down. It's as if they used a quarter of the powder they should be using and the melting ice didn't help out either.

This place is awesome for staying consistent with their ingredients!
author: Ced C.

description:
Definitely one of the more authentic and better tasting boba places in the city. From just one sip, you can tell that this place is legit and doesn't use powder or some sort of pre-made mix. Another huge plus about this place? There's almost never that long of a line. When you look out the door and see lines out the door for T-Pumps or for Teaway, part of you feels somewhat proud for knowing that you're getting the better tasting milk tea for almost no wait. My favorites include the Almond Milk Tea, Milk Green Tea, and the Lychee Milk Tea.

If boba isn't enough to satisfy your sugar cravings, do not fear because this place is littered with candy all throughout the store. Whether you want some gummies or some Asian candies, this place has it all. It's a "pay by weight" type deal, so you're able to get as much or as little as you'd like. 

Nestled on the side of Irving St. where a plethora of other dessert shops exist, Wonderful Foods definitely holds its own and is a very solid dessert stop. I would definitely recommend paying a visit out here.
author: Aaron W.

description:
Came here today (12/31/14) and ordered 3 drinks total. Total came out to $9.99. I paid $20 and owner gives me back $0.01 change. 

She places my $20 under the drawer and grabbed a $10 bill in her hand and got distracted by a man sitting next to her. She places the $10 back in the register and ASSUMED that I gave her that $10 when I clearly gave her $20. The owner refused to give me back my change...

So now I'm down $10. I paid $20 for 3 drinks. What a deal.

NEVER AGAIN. This establishment does NOT live by the phrase "the customer is ALWAYS right." Customer Service is nonexistent. 

I will NOT be back.
author: Johnny G.

description: The shop is very popular. Lots of people are waiting there. A friend highly recommended this shop. The environment is nice and the staff are so kind. They offer many kinds of milk tea, sugars, dry fruit, nuts and fried things.  We ordered salt & pepper chicken and fried tenpura . They taste so good. It really deserves a try.
author: Nancy S.

description: Best boba on Irving. High quality boba that actually has the tea flavor you are asking for without all of the long lines. I will definitely be coming back if I am in the area. Note, it's cash only so make sure you have cash on hand. If not, there are multiple banks in the area.
author: Breniel L.

description:
Oooh have I found THE boba place? The Milk Tea Tapioca here is just the right amount of milk, tea, and sugar level! Needless to say the tapioca was perfectly chewy as well.

I think I've found the perfect boba in San Francisco
author: Vivian W.

description:
The best option for boba on Irving. And yes, there are many options. I love that the tapioca balls at this place are so soft and easy to chew. I literally get tired of chewing boba from Quickly / Teaway / T-Pumps. But with this boba, I have no qualms.

I usually go for the Almond Milk Tea. It is so milky and refreshing, with just the right amount of sweetness.

There's also a huge selection of candy for those of you with a sweet tooth!
author: Greg J.

description:
At first I was afraid, I was terrified...cause honestly this place does not look like the type of place to serve really good boba. This is definitely one of those "don't judge a book by its cover" type situations. There isn't huge signage (minus the one that says best tapioca in town on the window) just a simple green awning. It has quickly become my regular go to spot for boba. This place is WAYYYYYY better than that Quickly's, Teaway, and Tpumps nonsense that's in the area (and a much shorter wait too). 

It is cash only so make sure you have at least $5 on you (most of the drinks are less than $5, unless you upgrade to the large size). I always get the Thai tea tapioca, because for some reason it tastes like milk tea to me, and the milk tea tastes like chocolate milk...but the ratio of drink to boba is perfect so you don't run out of boba before your finish your drink and you don't have leftover boba with no drink to drink.
author: Megan J.

description:
My favorite place for bubble tea on Irving. With the no-nonsense interior and mix of American gummies and Chinese snack (dried fruits/dried squid, anyone?), the draw is truly the product and not any gimmicky design that gets in the way of your boba fix!

I've been here a bunch of times, and yesterday, our Thai iced tea was a bit too sweet and taro shake a tad too thick, but overall, I can't complain. The bubbles are always the perfect level of chewiness. A must-visit!
author: Shendi X.

description:
This shop is the one we used to go to as high schoolers. You know, when boba was JUUUUUUUST beginning to break onto the scene, and Wonderful Foods was pretty much the only place to get it.

They've moved locations since high school to this shop (across the street and down a block from the original place), but the boba is still top notch. Still. And they have great flavor options.

Avocado shake boba is my jam. And even at $4.75 a pop, I still can't let it go.

A ton of people have gone here and loved the boba. So yeah, you know that. What you might NOT know is (1) their staff is super friendly, (2) they have those little mini toy/figurine machines in the back, including a Hello Kitty eraser toy for $1 that comes out in a plastic canister SHAPED LIKE HELLO KITTY (like OMG!!!) with a slot so it can be used as a bank, and (3) they have those giant blue gummi sharks here, sold by the 1/4 pound. If you're like me and have been on the hunt for said GIANT gummi sharks, then you know just what a find this is.

So come here for the boba, and enjoy the hospitality and random cool stuff! :)
author: Audrey J.

description:
I always come here with either Natasha H. or Gloria C. on our usual nightly boba runs.  Back when I started school at UCSF, Gloria C. and a few of our friends made a Boba Night Clique--and we did exactly as you'd think--came to Outer Sunset to have our nightly boba.  Speed forward a few years, and here I am -- still coming to this wonderful family-owned joint for luscious tapioca balls and sweet milk tea.  Wonderful foods does their tapioca right--just the right consistency and at a really good price.  I usually get their #1 "bo ba nai cha" for a good price of $2.75.  Indeed, it may be a little more pricier than other boba joints like Quickly's, but they use fresher ingredients (i.e. actual tea, NOT tea powder!) than just the usual nasty powders they use at Quickly's. You definitely pay for QUALITY here, not quantity.  

Besides selling an array of tapioca drinks, they have lots of candies for sale and Chinese dried snack goods (such as preserved plums, dried mandarin peels, and dried fish sticks) -- not for everyone's palate, but still--a large array of things to eat and drink.  

The owners here are really nice and are friendly, and they also have two cute little Bichons that they bring to the store.  So a lot of times my friends and I come here drink our boba and pet the dogs.  It's a very enjoyable and stress-relieving experience.  What more can you ask for?

I've been a fan of this joint ever since I've moved to San Francisco, and I will continue to be a patron of this wonderful boba place.  Hmm, gei wo yi ge bo ba nai cha ba!
author: Matthew L.

description:
Wonderful is definitely one of the longest standing boba shops in SF. They are very traditional in the way that they do things and how they run their business. 

But that's the problem.

Wonderful is always empty nowadays. It's not because they aren't good either. With so much competition nowadays, Wonderful really needs to step their game up. It's coming to a point where even loyal customers are dwindling. New boba shops just have so much more to offer.

I do however like Wonderful for the fact that they are one of the last places in SF to still have papaya milk. That alone will keep me coming back.
author: David Z.

description:
dude.....yelp......you screwed me over. 
I took a trip to sf, and I knew I had to find me some bomb milk tea so I decided to talk to my handy friend yelp to see who was the best and Wonderful comes up, ok if you say so yelp I was willing to give it a try. no. no. no. 

I ordered their original milk tea and omg it was awful seriously had a weird coffee like taste. Their coworkers seemed rude as well, pretty disappointed. Do not go here.
author: Stephanie D.

description:
Been a fan of this place since it was in its original location. I've always loved their milk tea. It always the same taste regardless of how many workers that have made it throughout the years. 

I am a fan huge fan of milk tea so every place that tends to open, I like to try just milk tea to find the best place. 

There's probably a handful places in the Bay Area that deserves a 5 star rating for milk tea and not that I like any of those listed below more than another but here are my favorite places you must check out

1. Wonderful 
2. Share tea
3. Fantasia

Tip: If you find that you can't finish a drink order have them split it to 2 cups. They will happily do that without extra charge for an extra cup. That's really great. CASH ONLY
author: Joanne K.

description: Interesting looking place.  I expected it to look like a typical bubble tea place.  It looked like a ma and pa shop, with a decent sized drink menu, along with candy, dried fruit, and random things sold throughout the store.  Interesting.  I'm curious to how their drinks taste.
author: Ivy T.

description: The boba was soft and chewy, which is perfect.  The flavor of the pineapple mango smoothie and the honeydew was only ok.
author: kyle c.

description:
I was discouraged from going to Purple Kow because of how far it was from where I was, so i decided to come here instead, which was a bit closer.
I have to say, i would have never pinned this place to get boba from the outside.
It looks like a typical Chinese cafe that sells dim sum or tea eggs.
I came here specifically for the boba so i didn't pay much attention to the desserts they sell, but they do sell bulk candy by the weight (think Sweet Factory at just slightly higher prices) too.
I got a passion fruit milk tea and my cousin got a lychee milk tea.
My PFMT was a surprise and a little different than I am used to (I get boba maybe 3 days a week, always trying new places). It wasn't as sweet as i'm typically used to which was a PLUS because the flavor was more natural than artificial.
My cousin deemed that his MT was okay, but we figured it was because he doesn't typically get lychee and that just wasn't his favorite flavor. His drink had bits of nuts(?) in it, which i didn't try but would assume were almonds or even the center around the nut of the lychee fruit from the looks of it.
The boba itself is okay, i've had better. It's a little more chewy and feels as though they've been sitting for too long and soaked up too much liquid on the outside, but the centers weren't hard which many places can screw up.
They definitely aren't cheap either. Their prices are on par with regular boba cafes that focus on boba.

The special thing about this place is that they offer real unique fruit boba drinks that your local Tpumps or Fantasia or Quickly (shoot me) don't.
I saw a Durian milk tea for $8, for example.
I've only seen the more specialty drinks in select Oakland Chinatown cafes, so if you're in the area and love boba, I'd definitely stop on by.

Don't be scared either, the cashier spoke English!
author: Connie T.

description: Indeed the best boba in San Francisco and is also the original boba shop in San Francisco. I remember them being next door to Quickly back in the early 2000s, I guess the moved across the street to avoid their competitors. Wonderful was the first boba shop on Irving before chains like Quickly, Teaway, and Tpumps opened. I usually go for the milk tea with boba or a smoothie on their menu. The milk tea is standard and was not too sweet or too bitter. I also get their strawberry banana smoothie which is made with real fruit, unlike other places that use syrups. I believe that for all the items on their drink menu comes with boba, as I was never charged extra for add ons. The boba here has a very good texture and the flavoring is also sweet. I really like the syrup that they use in their boba, I would sometimes come here to buy their boba and add it to random drinks. The service here is quick and friendly, there is never a line to order. They also offer candy by the pound with a reasonable selection, but that is a bit on the pricy side on my opinion.
author: Peter C.

description:
Ambiance of a restaurant is sorta like sex....yeah try sexing up a homeless dude in GG park.....I know that was a disgusting mental picture (I apologize).

Well since Tpumps was line out the door crazy...and the yelp reviews were mixed....I decided to try Wonderful foods company. It was dubious from the get go...there was no one in there....two girls (I assume were help) eating take out chinese food from somewhere else (that was attractive). The girl behind the counter was cool and efficient...the mango boba was okay.....but the place just looks tired, dirty and old.

Candy in the front had been there since the Broderick/Terry duel...it looked really old.

The funky handmade menu signs...with the added new additions of fried shrimp balls and other delights....ugh.

Yelp you let me astray on this one.
author: David G.

description:
Best boba in the city! They still use real EVERYTHING, not that powder stuff you'll get at all the other places. That's also why prices are slightly higher. That being said, my favorite is the mango tapioca. My friend said it tastes different, but that's because she's used to the powder, syrup stuff. The mango tapioca is much thicker here. 

Usually when I invite my friends, I always suggest the lychee juice with coconut jelly with tapioca. If you don't like coconut, don't worry. It doesn't taste anything like coconut, just lychee. Never had a person say they didn't like it. 

Sometimes there's a line, but not usually. They make the drinks VERY quickly. They actually opened another store over in the richmond district called Sweet Hut. Guess they're doing pretty well!

This place also sells tons of candy. Makes me think back to the days when Stonestown still had Sweet Factory. They sell some food as well, but I never really order the food. 

Overall, this is my boba hot spot. I use to come here multiple times a week. If you need suggestions, here's a list of my favorite drinks:

Cold drinks: Mango tapioca, Strawberry Smoothie Tapioca, Almond Jelly Tapioca in Honey, Lychee Juice with Coconut Jelly
Hot drinks: Almond Tapioca, Taro tapioca
author: Jessica Y.

description:
I was never really into milk tea until I tried this place. The only drink I've had here was their Jasmine Green Milk Tea, but it's so good that I keep coming back whenever I find myself in their neighborhood. They give a lot of boba with their drinks, and it's a lot better than the hard stuff other stores give you. Unfortunately, I got my dog hooked on their boba, so whenever he sees me with a to-go coffee cup, he assumes I have boba to feed him (oops...).

If you order their hot drinks, they just take the cold drinks and microwave it. If you order your drinks hot, they also charge you an extra $0.25 to microwave your drinks. I don't mind paying a little extra for it, since my drink costs about $3 with the extra charge, but I thought it would be good to know and share. How hot the drinks are also differs depending on the person making the drink. I've had it from lukewarm to scorching, tongue-burning hot.

In addition to the drinks, they also sell tea eggs and a large variety of candy. Keep in mind that this place takes cash only, so make sure you have some on you when you visit!
author: Tina T.

description: Their avocado tapioca is on point. Tastes fresh and the best part, it doesn't have that powdery texture most milk tea bars have. Also, their popcorn chicken is very much tasty! Not too much batter which is just the way I like it. Not to mention the crispness ...
author: Johnny N.

description: Amazing fruit smoothie! I got a mango pineapple lychee smoothie. They use fresh fruit and they are open late.
author: Samar S.

description:
I used to really love Wonderful and would have given Wonderful 5 stars 2-3 years ago. However, I now find the drinks way too sweet even when I asked for less sugar. I'm not sure if the drinks have changed a lot in the past few years or if my taste buds have changed. The best time I find to buy a boba from Wonderful is when I have a big sweet tooth craving! I would recommend trying the oatmeal milk tea for a different experience from typical boba shops.

The candy selection is also a very nice touch. My favorite is the chocolate covered gummy bears. Highly recommend people trying it at least once.

Pros:
- Good place to satisfy a really big sweet tooth craving
- Has the very unique oatmeal milk tea
- The candy selection is always very fun to dig around

Potential Improvements:
- Lower the overall sweetness of the drinks and give customers and option to make it sweeter or less sweet
- Add more seating. I have friends who live in the area, I would like to have a place to sit and socialize, but there is only 4 seats currently
author: Jeff M.

description:
I'm a little disappointed that this is the most highly rated bubble tea in SF because I found it to be basic at best. 

I got almond milk tea with tapioca less sweet, and I found it to be too syrupy and not have any tea flavour. Same with the lychee milk tea. The avocado smoothie was pretty decent though if you asked for less sweet. 

The pearls were a little on the soft side for my taste. This place is also cash only but at least it's open really late.
author: Waanmathi V.

description:
I'm the kind of person that gets a guilty feeling when giving two stars to a place that overwhelmingly gets four and five star reviews. I mean, when a place like Wonderful Foods has almost entirely four and five star reviews I feel like, yes, this place is going to have the best boba in the City. But, alas, I was really underwhelmed.

Maybe I've been living in Taipei too long, maybe I'm just "too" Taiwanese, but the boba at Wonderful Foods was not wonderful.

During my last visit to San Francisco my friend took me to Wonderful Foods having heard a lot about it himself. Both interested in what all the hype was about, we decided we had to try this place.

Mai3le5:
- Tapioca Milk Tea
- Almond Milk Tea with Boba

Upon entering the shop I was a little taken aback by the "ghetto-ness", but often times it's these types of places that have the best stuff. Also, I heard the lady behind the counter speaking some Taiwanese so I immediately had high hopes.

I decided that I'd get the standard Tapioca Milk Tea. I feel like the best way to test a tea place is by getting the most basic of teas because if you can't get that right...I appreciated that I was able to customize my drink since I don't like drinks of any sort that are too sugary; however, I found the tea to be rather watered down...Now, I don't know if it's because I got my tea with only 1/3 sugar that it ended up watery, but there really isn't any reason that the sugar content should effect the consistency of the drink. Also, the boba was kind of mushy :( I never expect perfectly "QQ" boba in the US, mostly because I rarely find it (I even used to work at a Tapioca Express in the college days), but this was barely even "Q". 

My friend got the almond milk tea, which was okay.

I feel like maybe we just came on an off day, or maybe we got the last of a batch, or maybe I'm just too picky about my boba and milk tea because I live in the land that originated the stuff. Whatever the reason I've definitely experienced better boba elsewhere.
author: Eifeh S.

description:
Literally the best boba in San Francisco. There are no scrolling pics of drinks on a flat screen TV. No fancy machines that seal drinks into the cup. There are no frills, no gimmicks, just straight forward drinks that taste delicious. The fresh fruit drinks are best. They never have a big line. And the boba is the perfect consistency. 


I wish they had more places to sit. But that's a small detail I'm willing to overlook. This place is that neighborhood spot that wins over all the other chains. Wonderfuls is wonderful.
author: Preston M.

description: They definitely have some of the best boba in the city. I always get the regular milk tea with boba. Everything is perfect (except the candy on the side of the walls - they're kind of stale).
author: Bing L.

description: This place is the best! Every Time i drive down to sf i have to get there honey dew milk tea  its like one of the best and there boba is like perfect. And there fried squid is a must!
author: Lily L.

description:
Sugar cravings? Satisfy your fix here with their candy selection and drinks!

The walls are lined with an assortment of American and Asian treats. They have candies like jawbreakers, licorice, gummies, and chocolates, as well as Asian treats like cuttlefish, plums, and dried fruits. 

The boba drinks my friends and I tried were just as sugary as their candy collection. Their Tapioca Milk Tea and Wintermelon Milk Tea was overpowered with sweetness, and hardly any tea flavor was noticeable.

On the bright side, they have my favorite popcorn chicken in the Bay. It's comes out hot and fresh, so there is several minutes' wait. The chicken is juicy and well-seasoned without being overly salty. The basil to top it off really adds to the flavor, too.

I'd pass on their drinks, but their popcorn chicken is a winner!
author: Tanya A.

description:
I have been coming to this place since I was a kid. The boba here is by far one of the best in town. My favorites are honey green tea, strawberry smoothie, and taro smoothie because they use real strawberries and real taro! I usually ask for less sugar so it's not too sweet since the fruit itself is pretty sweet already.

They also have really good basil popcorn chicken and hot grass jelly, which has red beans, green beans, and boba. Cash only though so make sure you bring cash!
author: Kally C.

description:
Shocked when I walked into the doors of this place, DANKY. Then I thought Damn, what did I expect people from San Francisco to know about boba anyways? With those 4 and a half stars, I really expected something else. 

I got an Apple drink with boba? Not sure if it was tea. Just some green drank poured out of a gallon jug from the fridge. 

I don't know, in Los Angeles we take our boba tea a little more seriously. There's no room for silly asian ladies to be serving these kind of pathetic beverages and getting almost 5 stars, it's real cut throat down here. I was just expecting a well crafted drink from an actual barista. 

Though the boba itself was edible. The drink itself was far below par.
author: Huy L.

description:
I guess I'll preface this review by saying I used to live in the 626 (San Gabriel Valley), where boba milk tea is basically a lifeblood. I had some really good boba down there and when I moved to SF, I tried to find a replacement. 

Wonderful Foods came up on my search and I figured that it was a must-try with its reviews. I made the trek out to Outer Sunset and upon arriving, I was surprised by the mom/pop-esque nature of the shop and the Chinese/English menu on the wall. I was hopeful. My go-to drink when visiting a boba place for the first time is a milk green tea with boba. I figure if the basics are good, then other teas are also probably good. That, plus you can get a good sense of boba consistency. 

That first time, and every time I've been since (about 5), the milk tea hasn't been amazing, is usually too sweet (even if I ask for less or half sweetness), and the boba is usually too chewy.  

With that being said, the tea is slightly better tasting compared to surrounding Outer Sunset boba places(Tpumps, Honeyberry, Teaway, Quickly). If you're trying to decide on a spot around the area, I'd say choose here over the other places.

Note: I'm giving this 3 stars for SF standards, but I think I might only give it a 2 if there were SoCal boba places up here.
author: Mario Z.

description:
Some of their drinks serve in fresh fruit instead of the powder, like the famous bubble tea shop in Chicago. However, i asked them not to add sugar, they still added brown sugar into my kiwi tapioca drink (i could tell when i drank it).

Another day I tried avocado tapioca but I add grass jelly instead. It's soooooo fresh and awesome. Love it!!! No sugar and no ice added. Feeling healthy.
author: Ashley C.

description:
I was stoked that this place actually had iced coffee boba! The interior isn't all that great, but with two walls of Asian and American candies, the lack of interior design didn't even matter.  

My boyfriend ordered the Taro Tapicoca and I had the Coffee Tapicoca.  Both were delicious! The cafe only accepts cash, so make sure you are ready! 

I would definitley come here again!
author: Amanda N.

description: Tapioca was great, chewy and plenty, while the milk tea was somewhat average. They also served interesting sweets like gummy fried eggs and steamed tea eggs. Not the most modern menu and decor like at Sharetea / boba guys, but probably a place I'd come back in the sunset.
author: Jaclyn C.

description:
I HATEHATEHATE when boba gets hard or isn't cooked right. Wonderful's boba was cooked to perfection. Chewy, gooey, and delicious. The milk tea is your average milk tea that you can't really go wrong with. But the boba was on point. 

It's a hole in the wall cash only place, and the walls are lined with candy and dried fruits. So it doesn't appear to be anything special, but that boba...so chewy =3
author: Jeff S.

description:
The best boba in the city?  Standards must not be very high then...

Now don't get me wrong, the boba is indeed very good.  I've just had comparably good boba at several Ten Ren's, Tea Station, Tea Six, Fantasia, etc.  I ordered the classic tapioca milk tea as my benchmark for all boba spots and it was solid - a bit too sweet even when I requested less sugar and more heavy-handed with the cream and condensed milk than I prefer.  The lychee tapioca milk tea, however, was very good and I loved the incorporation of actual lychee into the drink.

Prices are very fair at $2.75 for the classic and $3.25 for the lychee.  Nice girl behind the counter as well and a wide selection of candies is available along the walls if you're in dire need of some sugar.
author: Eric F.

description: Their jasmine milk tea was really good but service was a little bit slow. They also sell candy
author: Esther L.

description:
Two delicious things that are hard to find:

The most perfectly cooked tea egg

Green bean drink (not powdered but real mung beans)
author: George K.

description: Been coming here for years! Good place to grab a quick milk tea (the only drink I get here). Nothing fancy here, no variety of cup sizes, no level of sweetness, but I love that it's simple. Occasionally, I like to get candies here and they are never old. Kinda sucks that it's cash only. Minus one star because sometimes the boba can be a little hard.
author: Crystal C.

description:
5 stars for my Strawberry smoothie tapioca and coconut jelly. So refreshing. 

I upped my 4 star rating to a 5 because the Salt and pepper chicken is absolutely orgasmic. $5 something for a generous amount of delicious fried chicken nuggets. They too the chicken with fried basil. I love love it!!

I love the candy selection here and the tea eggs. Oh how i love tea eggs. This really My
Favorite boba spot in San Francisco. I don't have time to wait in TPumps REDICULOUS line.
author: Andrew V.

description:
Wonderful Foods, or as I like to call it, Wonderfoods.  This place truly does have drinks that does wonder!  My go to drink is the strawberry smoothie tapioca.  The right amount of sweetness combined with fresh tapioca balls, perfect on a hot sunny day. 

They have a large menu of drinks to choose from.  One day, I decided to try the green apple tapioca and lychee tapioca with grass jelly.  The green apple was too sweet for my liking.  The lychee tapioca was quite deceiving; I thought it was lychee flavored milk tea but nope, it was milk tea with bits of lychee.  

This place is a great alternative to Purple Kow.  My only suggestion is, please add more balls!
author: Linda N.

description:
Decided to stop by this highly-reviewed spot to kill time with my boyfriend after a concert at Yoshi's SF. Was surprised to see such an empty shop with a really small menu and self-serve candy containers lining the sides. I actually liked that there weren't too many drinks to choose from since I'm really indecisive when it comes to food and drinks. 

We got boba milk tea and green bean slush. Might possibly be the best green bean drink I've ever had and I've tried it from a lot of different places (yes, I know it sounds/looks gross). The milk tea had a surprising coffee taste too it and was a bit too sweet imo, but it was definitely authentic and now I know to ask for less sugar
author: Estelle C.

description:
I was a little sketched out when I saw the place. It looks shabby and they were selling self serve candy in the front. Music fitting for a Castro nightclub was also blasting on full volume. But I went ahead and ordered their plain tapioca milk tea. Was really surprised! Tea is strong and I loved the texture of the tapioca balls. They listened well on my sugar level requests and the drink wasn't watered down with ice. Price was also great for only $2.75. 

Don't forget, cash only!
author: Winnie T.

description: forgot that had been before but walked in again.  they could improve the smell of the place.  mango smoothie with fruit, milk, etc. and boba ok.
author: Rob C.

description:
Wanted to satisfy my milk tea craving after downing some chinese food down the street.  I remember my friend Erika C. mentioning about this place in the past so I decided to check it out!

I ordered the milk tea and I loved it! I also got to try the green tea and it was the perfect amount of sweetness, which I usually find bitter tasting at other boba joints.  The drinks were light and absolutely delicious!

and fyi.. CASH ONLY!

Definite stop next time I am on this busy area of town! :)
author: Kathy D.

description:
I honestly wasn't expecting much from this place. One of my friends from San Francisco always raves about this place so when I had the chance, I immediately ordered my to-go boba drink (Taro Milk Tea with boba).

I thought it was kinda cute that the lady at the counter asked me, "Is that the purple drink?". 

All in all, I was satisfied with the drink and I thought it was the right amount of sweetness and didn't taste "off" like other boba shops. The boba tasted fresh and complimented the drink well. I'm pretty sure they use powder for their drinks, but it still tastes legit. I would definitely come again if I made the trek to Irving St. again.
author: Eva L.

description:
I love putting balls in my mouth. 

The tapioca kind, you sickos.

I feel like boba places generally have lower reviews so I was really excited to see such a highly rated boba place a few blocks from where I ate dinner last night.  I couldn't decide on a drink so I settled for the lychee milk tea because apparently it's the thing to get here. 

Ugh, COULD. NOT. SWALLOW.

The tea, you pervs.

I'm pretty sure they just take canned lychees and mush them up, then pour in the boba and milk tea. It is not flavored by a syrup. The bottom of the cup has lychee "pulp" instead. It's not a good combination, milk tea and lychee pulp. Maybe I'm just not Asian enough to appreciate it? Aside from that, the boba tasted old and overcooked to me too. It takes a lot for me to throw away food that I just paid for (I definitely have that Asian "get your money's worth" gene.) and I chucked my drink into a trashcan about three blocks from this place.
author: Jenn C.

description: im actually not a huge bubble tea fan or anything close to being a connoisseur, but my friends who are just that swear by this unassuming little cafe, so i have tried their drinks a few times. i tend to stick with traditional flavors - red bean, lychee, coconut, etc., but they have SO MANY options! recently a friend got the green apple, there is also durian, taro, and the list goes on and on.  there are only two people working behind the counter typically, so there can be a bit of waiting if youre there at a popular time.  it also doesnt look super duper clean...but ya know, chinese cafe shop!  they sell a huge selection of random candies and traditional preserved items..!
author: Christina L.

description:
I'll keep this short:

-Best green tea that doesn't need hella flavor like Tpumps.
-They're not stingy with tapioca like most places.
-I wish I could marry their french fries.
author: Puka N.

description: I've come to like Wonderful a lot more over time. Compared to the other boba shop fads that come and go (Teaway, Purple Kow, Tpumps, etc), Wonderfuls just seems to be a solid boba shop to go to. The real fruit drinks, solid boba will allow this shop to succeed over time in a city that's filled with boba shops.
author: Jeffrey H.

description: This is my place to go to for watermelon juice. They have chewy tapioca and it's the best. I like this place better than half and half.
author: con c.

description:
I was actually led here by Sweethut- a sister location that has AMAZINGG popcorn chicken and Wonderful Dessert & Cafe did not fail to disappoint! The "salt & pepper chicken" tasted identical- crispy, tender, and bursting of flavor. Could obviously tell that MSG was used but doesn't really bother me. If you ask for "spicy", keep in mind that their spicy is not very consistent. Sometimes, the chicken is full on red. Today, it was barely sprinkled with whatever spice they use.

BUT..read this.

I decided to get one of their drinks for the first time today. GROSSOMATIC. The honeydew tapioca tasted exactly like watered down melon hi-chew. Boba was chewy but lacked flavor, so I felt like I was eating artifical-flavored candy. I didn't expect much for a $3.25 drink, but I had my fair share of artificial honeydew tapiocas and this one was just straight-up nasty.
author: Michelle S.

description:
I ordered Tapioca Milk Tea ($2.75). It is pretty  good, but it has a hint of a coffee taste so if you are not a fan of coffee, I'm not sure that you would like it. I am alright with coffee so it's pretty good to me. 

My friends ordered Matcha Tapioca ($3.75) and Taro Tapioca ($3.25). They are only okay. They noticed the flavored powder. 

I think the tapioca is a bit too soft for my liking, but my friends seemed to like the softness of the tapioca. 

Bottom line: Try the regular milk tea!
author: K T.

description:
I came here on a Saturday afternoon, it was my first time. I ordered their regular tapioca milk tea. I thought it was very yummy and the tapioca was perfect texture!!

The milk tea itself had the perfect balance of milk & black tea. It was also not too sweet or watered down with ice.

I'd definitely come back! Cash only though!
author: Abby M.

description:
Hands down the best milk tea and boba. Also love the guava green tea and watermelon juice. 

Sometimes, drinks can be inconsistent, but this largely depends on the person making the drink.
author: Jane Y.

description:
Wonderful Foods Co has such an extensive menu; there are probably over 50 drinks available!  I wish I could say that I've tried out most of them by now, but I just usually stick to classic milk tea.  It's always delicious.  There is a good amount of tea flavor, with a nice amount of sweetness (not overly sweet or milk).  I also really like their boba because it has a nice chewiness to it.  It's not too jello-y and not hard either.  It always seems to be freshly prepared and compliments their drinks quite nicely.

Besides the drinks, I think what makes Wonderful Foods Co stand out is the service.  I've been here a few times and asked them to separate my drink into two cups, so that I can share with a friend, and they are always more than happy to accommodate me.  On top of that, they use nicer cups, with real lids.  (I don't really like the seal-on tops that rip open when stabbed with the boba straw.)  I'm a fan!

Notes:
-Street parking can be difficult at times.  But you'll find a space eventually.
-Friendly service.
-Vending machines dispensing cute little keychains/toys.
author: Samantha L.

description:
Tapioca honestly doesn't get more wonderful than this.

I'm a fiend for tapioca, and this is my numero uno spot for quality boba drinks. Even their original tapioca milk tea soars far and beyond that of Quickly's or TeaWay. It may be a little pricy for the broke college student, but I'd rather be paying for quality boba drinks than for powder.
author: Angelo M.

description:
Wonderful indeed!

I ordered the regular milk tea with boba and pudding. It did not disappoint. I've had better pudding, but their drink was great. It wasn't too sweet and had a really good flavor to it. It reminded me of Taiwanese milk tea. Definitely a place to come back to!
author: Christine V.

description:
Been coming here since middle school, and their quality has always been great!

I went through a tapioca/boba phase in high school and now I'm older, wiser, trying to be healthier or some crap, so I usually don't get ballz in my drinks, BUT if you like ballz in your drink, you'll want these ballz because they're sweet, just the right chewiness, and always fresh!
Their great variety of milk teas and smoothies are all delicious, fresh, and flavorful!

You can customize your drink by telling them how much of the ballz you want, how sweet you want it, etc etc etc & whatever those other fancy ass tea places do, but they don't put it on the menu because that's just clutter. If there's something wrong with your drink, they'll happily fix it for you (and sometimes let you keep the one they messed up too!)

Great customer service, friendly staff, usually no line, & high quality drinks for good prices!

Don't settle for Quickly or Teaway. You wanna wait in that ridiculous TPumps line? Didn't think so! 
WF also has an amazing candy selection that I can rarely resist. I love my gummies and they have SO MUCH YUMMINESS in that store. Ahhhh~~~~ writing this makes me wanna go get some now....

K see ya there, baiiiii~~~~~

Ballz (hehe)
author: Melissa Y.

description: Love their passion fruit green tea. Ask for 50% sugar. They tends to be sweeter than normal.
author: sam c.

description: Fruit drinks are loaded with fruit. The only thing is sugar is added to the drinks so I don't know if there's an option to say less sweet like many other boba drinks places in the city. Very reasonable prices though.
author: W A.

description:
Food - 4
Service - 3.5
Atmosphere - 3.5

Overall - 4

The boba here is a fresh taste compared to your traditional boba stores. It isn't overhyped like Teaway and it isn't overpriced like many of the other places. Just seems like a humble boba shop with good quality milk tea and good quality pearls.
Get the green tea milk tea if you want, as it's one of the best I've ever had. 

Honestly there's nothing more to write besides the fact that this is probably one of the most quality milk tea joints you'll ever hit up and it has an interesting backdrop too. There's very minimal seating (4 seats) but the place is lined with rows of candy bins, just like you would see in a candy store. People come in and out grabbing a bag and snacking on some candy, although I'd be advised because I don't know how long they've been in there.

Come in, come out and go on your way with a delicious cup on boba!
author: Dion W.

description:
This place is OG San Francisco Boba Tea.  Before there was PurpleKow, Quickly, Babmu and hipster places like Bobaguys, there was Wonderful. They're so OG they don't even have the sealing machines for the tea -- they just put a lid on the thing.  If you went to Balboa or Washington and speak SF Chinglish so thick that people who went to Lowell can't understand you, Wonderful is your place.  You probably won't go anywhere else for boba tea.  

Keep the spirit alive.  

(The milk tea is pretty darn good too).
author: howie f.

description: The traditional Chinese candy on the right had side of the entrance is a good sign of what's to come... Because dang this place is authentic and yummy! The passion fruit green tea tastes just like Taiwanese boba tea except for the lack of seeds. The tapioca texture was the best I've ever had in the US (better than I've had in SoCal). I only hope this wasn't a fluke, looking forward to coming back again!!
author: Alisha M.

description: Been coming here since I was a kid. I get something different almost every time. The most recent was a chocolate shake/slush and it was so chocolaty and creamy. The people working are always really nice and helpful when I ask for their opinion on what to get. One of my favorite parts is that they have a wide variety of candy and snacks and are usually open late so whenever I need a quick snack I know I can always come here.
author: Shannon M.

description: It's open late. They have a large assortment of candy. When I disliked my drink the server made me another.
author: Fernilla S.

description:
5 Star boba
3 Star overpriced candy 
4 Star Average +1 star for being open on Xmas 

The place has the best boba in the neighborhood.
author: Tommya D.

description:
Can't go wrong with a drink from Wonderful Foods, always great. Glad to see Teaway lose their hype with their poor quality (sorry to say).

My friend recommended me to the strawberry mango smoothie, which I enjoy, and I also like their Lychee Tapioca Milk Tea.

For those Durian lovers, be sure to try out their Durian Tapioca Milk Tea, but it is on the pricey side. ($6+)

Best in the city, hands down.
author: Sam K.

description:
Not just for Boba! The walls were lined with candy and the menu has lots of dessert drinks for you.

Four stars because I've had a bit of inconsistency with the boba (ordered the cocoanut drink a few times and the first time was way better than the second) but I stop in here once in a while to grab a bag of those sugar-coated sour strips.

Sweet childhood throwbacks!
author: Christophe C.

description:
I had the honey green tea, with lychee fruit. The sweetness was right on. The flavor was perfect. I've had this same drink at other places. Tea Papa for example, it almost has a slight soapy taste to the tea. The foam in the drink from Tea Papa might be adding to the soapy perception. The lychee fruit was cut up, so that its the size of jelly, vs being huge chucks; I liked that.

Also had some of my friend's Thai Tea w/ pearls. The tea was one of the best that I've had. 

But the reason this place gets 5 stars, the pearls were perfect. Just the right texture, consistency, and sweetness to them. I didn't used to think that you could screw up pearls. But I have learned long ago, that not all pearls are the same.
author: Benny N.

description: Wow, I haven't been here in years! But wonderful foods is just as consistent as it was a few years ago, which is a very good sign. Really janky and Asian inside, with a huge selection of Asian dried fruits and candies.. Can't forget the typos (tapioNca...lololol). Nonetheless.. The drinks have a nice tea flavor without being overly sweet and the tapioca is really nice and chewy and slightly sweet. The green milk tea wasn't too milky and was only $2.75! Definitely a better alternative to sugar crazy teaway or Tpumps.
author: Vivian C.

description:
This place was okay as far as drinks go, but the service irked me a little bit, especially in comparison to a lot of customizable milk tea places. In short, I don't get the hype, and I probably wouldn't return.

This is a small sweets shop with literally one table and two walls lined with candy and Asian dried fruits sold by price per pound. I didn't try any of those, but they have a lot of variety.

I opted for the almond milk boba while my friend got the avocado boba. I asked for less sugar, less boba, and less ice in mine, and the lady behind the cashier nodded and smiled the whole time. I thought that was a good sign, but when I got my drink, it was literally one-fourth filled with boba pearls and half-filled with crushed ice so that it was super cold. I really wasn't impressed, but I let it go and just drank (or tried to drink) the drink. The almond milk tasted like the artificial mixed kind you get from those pudding packets at Asian supermarkets. I've made my own almond milk at home many times, so that kind of artificial almond taste didn't sit well with me. It was okay because there are times when I go out for say, dim sum, and they serve almond pudding with a similar taste, so it wasn't horrendous, but it definitely wasn't real almond milk. The sweetness wasn't too bad, but going off of how my requests for less boba and less ice were ignored, I doubt it was less sugar. I maybe finished a third before tossing it.

My friend's avocado smoothie wasn't bad. It had perhaps a little less condensed milk in it than other places so it was a little less sweet, which is good, although that makes the color a little darker green and not as aesthetically pleasing (which is of course the less important factor). It also had a ton of boba pearls dispersed on the bottom, and when I tried it, I got a mouthful of pearls from just one sip. Their pearls aren't bad though; good texture and not too sweet, but the overabundance of them in both drinks got tiring really quickly.

In a time when milk tea shops are popping up everywhere, I'm just not too keen to return to a place that doesn't care about customer requests, especially when it's saving them ingredients.. I don't really understand why they would refuse something like that when it benefits both parties. Plus the prices aren't cheap either ($8.50 for a durian smoothie!), which makes me wonder if they're just well-established enough in the area to warrant them. There were only one or two customers on a Friday evening though, whereas T-pumps across the street had a line out the door; maybe I'll try there next time I'm in the area.
author: Maggie X.

description:
I've been here so many times already and I can never get tired of the same drink I order every time.

A little history: from what I remember, this shop has been around for awhile. It was one of the first milk tea shops opened on that street. I believe they were also at a different location awhile back. 

First impression: 
it has a giant green banner in the front of the shop. So you can't really miss it. 
Small little shop that sells both American candy and asian candy. It feels very asian authentic here. Haha. The American candies are a little pricy per pound. 
Only 2 small tables with maybe 4-6 seats? Wish there was more. 
They have a single bathroom here for you to use. Clean enough for you to use.
VERY unique menu. 4/5

Edibles:
I always order the white almond milk tea large there. Some times with pearls and sometimes not. Sadly though, after awhile, I started to notice the powdery finish to it. ): still a good drink though. 4/5
As for food, I LOVE the spicy onion rings. Crispy on the outside, soft on the inside. It's kinda salty, but the taste of drinking my milk tea after biting into the onion ring is a thrill. 3/5

Overall, I like it. It's nice to get away from all those hype milk tea shops.
author: Melanie L.

description: Been coming here for over 20 years, their drinks are not as sweet as their competitors. Plus they know me so they hook it up!
author: Fabiola V.

description: 5 stars for the boba. 2 stars for the drink. A friend told me about this place and it seemed to have good reviews. Aesthetically, the place wasn't great, but I decided to go for it and not judge a book by its cover, so to speak. I got a basic green milk tea with boba. It was very cheap which was great! The boba was just right and very delicious! However, the milk tea itself was too sweet for my liking. I like being able to taste the tea flavor in my milk teas, and my drink was just too sweet, and tea wasn't strong enough. There was only a hint of green tea. I think I would go back to give it another try by getting a different flavor maybe, but not likely because of the level of sweetness. Unlike Sharetea, Craftea, and Teaway, the option to change the level of sweetness isn't offered.
author: Christina C.

description:
There's nothing special about this place. The tapioca pearls were slightly mushy when I went around 8:30pm on a Saturday night. They're nowhere as bad as Quickly's can get so I wouldn't say to avoid it.

The mint green tea was decent. It had a good amount of mint syrup without overpowering the tea flavor.

I found the tapioca green milk tea pretty bland. I wouldn't recommend it.

The salt & pepper chicken was pretty good. We were wondering if it was chicken wings or popcorn chicken because the menu didn't specify (it was popcorn chicken). It was flavorful and wasn't just a bag of batter and crumbs.
author: Cammie W.

description: One of my favorite boba spots in SF. Fresh watermelon juice is my favorite here. Boba is always nice and chewy and I love that they sell sour belt candies!
author: Joyce C.

description:
My favorite spot in the city to get tapioca drinks hands-down! I love how it's a mom-and-pop store and not a chain store like Quickly. 

Their pearls are always soft and chewy. I love their milk tea tapioca, Thai iced tea, fresh watermelon, strawberry smoothie, and fresh mango. The bf enjoys their fresh kiwi drink.

I will always come here for my tapioca fix!
author: Fallon P.

description:
A favorite local joint loved and craved by many.
I for one do not like tapioca balls but majority of their drinks are good and you have a option if you want a fresh smoothie or tell them you want a powdered drink.

I came here sick once and asked if they could mix my emergen-C into my drink and they gladly did that! ^_^
author: Jenny Y.

description: Best boba in town? My friends and I were pretty skeptical when we saw that on the window but decided to try it anyway. It doesn't really look that nice inside so my expectations were pretty low. I ordered the Thai Tea w/ boba and I dunno if it was the "best" boba but the boba was pretty good. Everyone else thought so too! The drink was also tasty and not too sweet. My bf also got their salt n pepper chicken and that was also really good. I wouldn't mind coming back if I was in this area again!
author: Sandra N.

description:
Where do you go for boba in SF? Do you go to Quickly's? Do you go to Tea Way? Do you go to Purple Kow? If you do, you're going to the wrong place!!! Ok, theirs might be cheaper, but you get what you pay for. I've been going to Wonderful Foods for the past at least 15 years. No doubt this is the best and original boba spot in the City. I just love their milk tea!!! If I want to change it up a bit, I'll get the lychee one (#3) or taro. I know many people who like the Avocado one, too. The boba is done pretty well here and they're consistent. Don't waste your money on the crap that is Quickly. They paid the now imprisoned ex-city official so they could get permits all over the city. Booooooo!!!!!

I love you, Wonderful Foods!!!
author: Aaron Y.

description: Their Almond milk is the best thing ever!!! My favorite!!!! They use fresh ingredients as well and real fruits for blended drinks!!!!
author: Jon L.

description: First time I came I didn't buy anything, just spent time examining the many many treats they had available. Second time in I got two teas: thai ice tea tapioca and almond jelly tapioca with honey tea. Both were very good, but also very sweet! Lots of tapioca balls (which are perfect texture and not sweet)!
author: Jessica R.

description:
Of all the tapioca/boba places, this place is one of a few that has retained its boba quality. It has the right density where it's chewy without being too mushy or hard.

Note, this is for the boba/tapioca, not for the liquid itself. All these other new fandango boba places can't keep their quality the same.

Even w/ asking for less sweet, it tends to still come out too sweet.
author: Tech G.

description:
Wonderful Foods has been around for ages and the boba here is good and has been kept the same this whole time which is quite amazing. The menu is expansive and it has a handful of fresh fruit juice options which is good if you are feeling healthy. Over the years, they have added many new items indicated by the pieces of paper stuck on the wall. 

The milk tea here is really good, tastes different from other boba joints but in a good way! I'm not sure what they use but it tastes a bit like coffee. I love the fresh watermelon juice with tapioca, always refreshing. 

There's a bathroom at this location which is perfect! 

The owner of this place opened another boba place called Sweet Hut in Richmond district. 

Parking is all meters and can be hard to find at times.
author: Maybo L.

description:
There's a reason why Wonderful's still stands up against all the other milk tea joints on this block: This place is THE OG . I remember as a kid going to it's old location across the street dressed in my discolored Pikachu pullover (you know what's up). 

Although the drinks are a bit pricier, most of them are made of real fruits instead of flavored syrups (give or take a few items). You can definitely taste the difference in freshness. The boba isn't too soft, but rather chewy. They don't skimp on it too - ahem, Tpumps. Also, they've perfected their milk to tea ratio here. Win, win!

As like any other place on Irving (aka Chinatown's baby), parking can be a B. But have no fear, if you make a couple of loops around the block, you'll probably find a spot as people come and go all the time.

Need recommendations? 
-Passionfruit green tea with light sweetness
-Pina colada
-Red bean milktea (with actual red bean in it) 
-Lychee milktea. 
For something more filling, I'd go for the mango smoothie or avocado smoothie. 

Deduct one star for CASH ONLY and lack of seating.
author: Ashley L.

description: Yikes, I was totally mislead by the other yelp reviews! My husband and I both got almond milk tea (25% sweet and 50% sweet) and it was as if they were 100% sweet and 200% sweet! The texture of the boba was good, but it was so sugary that it was nearly undrinkable. Not really a nice place to sit and enjoy either. Super bummed because we live close by.
author: Grace W.

description:
Best bubba drinks!!  Always fresh.

Most tea place serve drinks using powders (translated chemicals).  Here, you have a choice and they use fresh taro, mangoes, avocadoes, strawberries, etc. for their drinks.
author: Terri N.

description: With the explosion of milk tea places all over Irving recently, I would probably still come here for a simple milk tea with boba if that's what I'm feeling. While not as customizable as what you'd get at say Teaway or TPumps, the quality here can be really tasted and doesn't feel like watery syrup or a medley of different flavors. The boba is quite good as well. And if you feel like a snack, their salt and pepper chicken is an excellent choice, which comes with a bit of basil for flavor in the bag.
author: Tony D.

description: I haven't had pearl milk tea in ages. We decided to drop by here where I ordered lychee green tea iced tea. I asked for "less sweet." I loved it! They add crushed lychee pieces (note- not lychee jelly!) which makes for interesting texture while you gulp down and chew the pearl balls at the same time. What I like about this place is that the green tea actually tasted strong and that the pearls on its own were not so sweet that you feel like you'll get cavities just chewing them.
author: Michelle T.

description:
Visited this place for the first time last night after seeing its high average rating and late night hours (was craving milk tea late at night).

Anybody that considers this place good is deluded. Upon entering I was immediately skeptical. The interior is essentially a candy store with a variety of western candy on the left and a interesting assortment of asian sweets on the right (some of which looked intriguing!). 

Upon reaching the counter I inspected their "kitchen" and noted that they had 1 tea dispenser and a wide assortment of powdered flavorings... not a good start. Ordered the Taro Tapioca ($3.25) and witnessed them make it. Hilariously simple addition of powder, tea and purple colouring with a big helping of tapioca. no shaking, no oil additions.... nothing that constitutes a good milk drink.

Terrible beverage which tasted overly sweet (I ordered 50% sugar) and left a cloying artificial taro flavor in your mouth. The boba itself was decent with a large helping and a moderately chewy texture albeit a bit lacking in flavor. 

With options like Bubble on Noriega, I-Tea across the street and Purple Kow in the Richmond there is literally zero reason to visit this establishment. Late hours being its only redeeming feature.
author: Gabriel W.

description:
There is a reason that this place has such a good reputation.  Forget Purple Kow (way overrated), Tpumps (also overrated), Quickly (oh please no), and all of the other boba places.  Wonderful Foods is the place to be.  Don't believe me? Here's why:

1. Short line
2. Wide selection
3. Reasonable prices
4. Great-tasting products

etc...

There are no mobs of Asian kids (I am Asian) loitering in and around it, which is a huge plus for me.  This is the real deal.  The two tapioca drinks I get are (1) milk tea with mango pudding, and (2) watermelon juice with lychee substituted for tapioca (trust me on this, it's delicious).  So good so good omg.  The only downside is that there is only one table, so it's not really a sit-down kind of place.  But no biggie.  Also, cash only, so be prepared.  Most of the drinks average around $3.75, which is more than reasonable.

Come here, and take me with you when you do.
author: David L.

description: Came for teaway next door for milk tea and popcorn chicken,but unfortunately they closed down, so ended up here. The place overall looks weird, only 2 sitting tables and not really comfortable. Ordered the original milk tea and popcorn chicken. The tea tastes funny and the chicken is too sweet to my taste. I really missed teaway next door and will not be back here.
author: Ying C.

description:
I finally tried Wonderful Foods after having bookmarked it for over 2.5 years! I ordered the taro smoothie, and wow, it was so good. They actually use real taro, which is unfortunately very rare, and the resulting drink is thick, creamy, and flavorful. My boyfriend got some other smoothies and teas here and absolutely loved it too! We had to come back the next day :)

Verdict: A must visit!
author: K W.

description:
This is the most legit, OG boba place ever! I think this place has been around ever since I was born. My mother also knows the owner lady. 

This place will always be awesome to me because it's so nostalgic. The candy and boba haven't really changed at all through the years and it's just nice to know that the business is making it. 

I love the boba milk tea here. It's different from teaway, quicklys, or tpumps but I can't tell you why. Probably nostalgia again. But I love the boba here. It's always chewy and sweet and consistently good, unlike teaway which has their boba sitting in a tub out in the open. 

T-pumps is new on the block and is all the rage, but it'll never beat Wonderful to me.
author: Becca W.

description:
I'm very wary when places proclaim that they have THE best anything in town, and I wasn't sure if SF could top San Gabriel Valley's tea. But my gawd, I'm glad Yelp didn't steer me wrong this time around!

Walk in, and it's a candy store. Make your way to the back, and it's a tea spot! Good selection of drinks. Everything was cheaper than I'm used to back at home (LA) by almost $1. I paid ~$2 for a black milk tea with boba (#1), and it was AMAZING. The taste was unique and nothing quite like I've ever had before when I can safely say I've traveled through plenty of places in Asia. The tea was incredibly strong and aromatic when usually the milk and sugar content is overwhelming at other places. The aftertaste was a tad bit bitter. Mmm, creamy and smooth. The boba was standard, but that's not a complaint.

Because we were in Oakland and we had just finished watching the Lakers get destroyed by the Warriors, there weren't too many tea places open. Even though Wonderful Dessert closes at midnight, it seems that that's still later than others. When we arrived, parking was easy for once. There was a small line, but the wait was absolutely minimal. Can I say that that's f***ing amazing? My drink was ready for me as soon as I tried to sit down. 

I came in a tourist asking myself if I was going to regret walking in, but I'm glad I can say that Wonderful Dessert got this tea snob/addict won over. Now where the hell am I going to find something comparable in SGV?
author: Ivy W.

description:
I can't say enough good things about this place. After 3+ years in SF and numerous boba excursions, this place still is my golden standard for quality boba.

Their boba has the perfect chewy, sweet texture and all their drinks are made fresh right in front of you, no mixed powders here.

It's not cozy or trendy, and it's not a place to sit and hang out, but if you want the best boba in the city without a wait for super cheap prices, this is the place to be.

They also have awesome candy, amazing fresh juice, and savory snacks as well. Cash only.
author: Kate M.

description:
If there's one thing I'll always have room for in my life, it's boba milk tea, and Wonderful Foods has got the flavor of the milk tea and consistency of boba down from Day 1!

I have been coming to this place since its early days (when they used to have their shop next to the current Quickly's), and I have to say, I have yet to try a place with better boba milk tea.  Maybe it is a little more expensive, but for the quality of boba and milk tea you get, it's totally worth it. The flavor is consistent every time and sweetness is adjustable. I appreciate how they don't skimp on the boba either. Trust me, once you try this place, any other boba milk tea won't measure up.  

The great service makes me happy! The super nice lady that works there recognizes me and knows my order by heart  (Large Number 1 no ice, less sweet!!) even though I don't go as often as I'd like now that I'm  studying down in LA.  Seating area is non-existent, so be prepared to grab-n-go. They also have a variety of cute little candies lined up along the entrance and Taiwanese snacks (tea-eggs, fried tempura, salt and pepper chicken) for sale.

Now if only they'd open a location closer to the heart of downtown so I wouldn't have to trek 45 minutes out from where I live when I am back in the bay just to get some delicious chewy balls and flavorful milk tea. 

I'm dedicated to this place. For the time being, I guess I'll have to settle with going out of my way to get some wonderful boba milk tea in the Outer Sunset!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
You can't be a foodie if you haven't tried wonderfuls. #byeposer lmao

Best boba in the Bay Area. My mom worked on Irving when I was younger, and I always got the avocado with boba! Nowadays, I still come here when I'm in the area and it's still as good. My hubby loves their taro, it's soooo fresh!
author: Crystal C.

description: Not so down. Cash only. Drinks are super sweet. Boba is way too chewy. The price is solid, but the food really isn't. They have some old school Asian sweets, but you can also get this stuff in supermarkets. Not coming back.
author: Danny C.

description: Arguably the best boba place in San Francisco... or at least the oldest?! Been coming here since the early 2000s, before the craze of Teaway (gross), T Pumps (eh), and all those other places on Irving. The milk tea is a little sweet for my tastes, but who cares. Strong tea flavor, nice consistency/texture, and if you love boba, this place prepares it the best.
author: Mark L.

description:
How the mighty have fallen.  This was the joint I was telling all my friends about for years, but it looks like they got too comfortable due to their success.  They have lost their consistency.  Their tapioca isn't as soft as it once was and the milk tea has been so-so at best.  I've been disappointed the last 3 to 5 times I've been there.  They've got a lot of new people working there now which might be the reason why their product has gone down hill a bit.  I've decided to use One More Cup Cafe on Judah going forward.

Hope Wonderful management gets their act together. They were one of the originals of the boba tea craze on Irving.  Judging by some of the recent reviews, I'm not alone.

Food - 1 star
Service - 3 stars
Value - 2 stars

Overall - 2 stars
author: Sunny W.

description:
*****5 STARS*****5 STARS*****5 STARS*****5 STARS *****5 STARS*****

I don't know any other place that sells tapioca that is as sweet, soft, chewy & perfect. Not only is it PERFECT, they give you A LOT TOO!!!!

I must have been crazy to give them 4 stars before, they don't deserve that.

REAL FRUIT & PERFECTLY MADE TAPIOCA =]
author: Kylie L.

description:
So, rumor on the street is that sour belts are my kryptonite. 

Back in the day when I was a young lad, id hang out in the mall arcade room dominating tekken, hit up sweet factory and go wild on sour belts. Because of this, I was introduced to a magnitude of dentist visits ultimately resulting in braces. To this day, I have a palate yearning for all things sour leaving my teeth begging for mercy.

Everything was fine and dandy... until I found wonderful foods co.

My FW Angie/winged woman/Ryans +1 and I discovered wonderful foods while leaving tuttimelon for a mountainous yogurt run. Since our sweet tooth already been tended to, we took a mental bookmark of our discovery and went on home. Only a few days passed and we made it a point to check it out during our daily/late night dessert run. 

When you walk in, you can't help but to notice the wall of teeth destroying goodness. I laid eyes on an array of sour goodies (belts galore) and went HAM. 
While I was overloading my bag, the FW was ordering the drinks. Rd. 1 she had the grass jelly juice and I went with my standard milk tea. The grass jelly transported her back to her childhood days just as the sour candy did for me. The second go around (a few days later, mind you) she went with the watermelon juice and we also tried the tea egg (and, okay, I got more candy). Everything thus far has been phenomenal. 

I am fortunate to live just blocks away so I can indulge at any time. My dentist bills, not so fortunate.

Collectively, we have decided that this is a less pretentious TPumps and better that quickly.
 
The candy selection just pushes it over from good to fantastic. Wonderful foods Co. ironically doesn't have a lot of food, but it does have some bomb ass candy and boba. And for this, you earn my business for a lifetime (or until my teeth rot, whichever comes first)
author: Ryan L.

description:
"Lick an orange. It tastes like an orange. The strawberries taste like strawberries! The snozzberries taste like snozzberries!" - Willy Wonka

Wonderful Foods Co. doesn't make chocolate or playfully murders children with orange midgets singing them to their doom but they certainly bring the boys to the yard with their unique Boba drinks and damn right, it's better than yours.  I'm sure that other Boba places offer some of these unique flavor combinations but the ambiance and non-pretentiousness puts this place over the moon for me.  I'm not much of a free Wi-Fi whore, so I don't tend to post up anywhere for very long, so the sparse furniture and aesthetic appeal doesn't influence my opinion of the shop.  

Ryan L./Cuffed Crusader/Angie's +1: Ultimately brought us to this fine establishment after walking past it from procuring way too much yogurt at TuttiFrutti and reverting back to a 4 year old whilst noticing an American candy selection in Little China Town/Sunset.  He ordered his daily craving of Milk Tea with tapioca and funneled it quickly into his gut.  His other cyclic craving was also pleasantly satisfied with their assortment of sour belts.
